MemberSignature.Value: public UIStepper (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When you invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty you taking advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to you.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is your responsibility to completely initialize the object if you chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if your constructors invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, you should instead chain to the proper constructor in your class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: public UIStepper (IntPtr handle);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. You should not invoke this method directly, instead you should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: public UIStepper (System.Drawing.RectangleF frame);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF frame) cil managed
public UIStepper (MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame) cil managed

Docs.param: Frame used by the view, expressed in iOS points.
Docs.summary: Initializes the UIStepper with the specified frame.

remarks.para: This constructor is used to programmatically create a new instance of UIStepper with the specified dimension in the frame. The object will only be displayed once it has been added to a view hierarchy by calling AddSubview in a containing view.
This constructor is not invoked when deserializing objects from storyboards or XIB filesinstead the constructor that takes an NSCoder parameter is invoked.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UIStepper.UIStepperAppearance Appearance { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIStepper/UIStepperAppearance Appearance

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.
Docs.remarks: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UIStepper.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UIStepper.UIStepperAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn (Type[] containers);
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIStepper/UIStepperAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that you want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that you can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where you can set appearance properties for instances of UIStepper when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public override IntPtr ClassHandle { get; }
.property instance native int ClassHandle

Docs.summary: The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.
